open_questions.title: Name some of the features of
open_questions.description: Name some of the features of the Java Programming language?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some of the features of the Java Programming language?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Java is a popular, high-level programming language known for its portability, security, and ease of use. Key features include: Object-Oriented: Supports OOP principles like inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation, and abstraction. Platform Independence: Compiled into bytecode that runs on any device with the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). Simple Syntax: Easy to learn, especially for those familiar with C and C++, with simpler syntax. Robust and Secure: Strong memory management, garbage collection, exception handling, and a security manager. Multi-threaded: Built-in support for concurrent programming. High Performance: Optimized through just-in-time (JIT) compilation. Distributed: APIs for networking and creating distributed applications. Dynamic and Extensible: Supports dynamic loading of classes. Rich Standard Library: Comprehensive APIs for data structures, networking, I/O, and UI design. Automatic Memory Management: Garbage collection to handle memory allocation and deallocation.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some ways Java is different
open_questions.description: Name some ways Java is different from C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some ways Java is different from C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Memory Management: Java: Automatic garbage collection. C++: Manual memory management using pointers. Platform Independence: Java: Compiled to bytecode, runs on JVM ("write once, run anywhere"). C++: Compiled to platform-specific machine code. Syntax and Features: Java: No pointers, supports interfaces, and has a simpler syntax. C++: Supports pointers, multiple inheritance, and operator overloading. Standard Library: Java: Rich standard library with built-in support for networking, multithreading, and GUI development. C++: Standard Template Library (STL) for data structures and algorithms. Performance: Java: Generally slower due to the JVM overhead. C++: Generally faster due to direct compilation to machine code. Object Orientation: Java: Purely object-oriented (except for primitives). C++: Supports both procedural and object-oriented programming. Exception Handling: Java: Built-in exception handling with try-catch-finally blocks. C++: Supports exception handling but less emphasized.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between Heap and Stack
open_questions.description: What are the differences between Heap and Stack Memory in Java?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the differences between Heap and Stack Memory in Java?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Purpose: Heap: Used for dynamic memory allocation for objects and instances. Stack: Used for static memory allocation, storing local variables and function call frames. Lifetime: Heap: Objects persist until they are no longer referenced and garbage collected. Stack: Variables are destroyed as soon as the function call ends. Access: Heap: Accessed globally via object references. Stack: Accessed locally, following LIFO (Last In, First Out) order. Management: Heap: Managed by the garbage collector. Stack: Managed by the function call structure. Performance: Heap: Slower access due to dynamic memory allocation. Stack: Faster access due to static memory allocation.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Is Java a platform independent language?" Requirements: - Answer the question directly, then explain - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: Java is platform-independent because its code is compiled into bytecode, which can run on any device with a Java Virtual Machine (JVM). The JVM interprets the bytecode into machine code specific to the host platform, enabling the same Java program to run anywhere without modification. This "write once, run anywhere" capability is central to Java's design.

open_questions.title: Object Cloning in Java
open_questions.description: What is Object Cloning in Java?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Object Cloning in Java?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Object cloning in Java creates an exact copy of an object using the clone() method. The object must implement the Cloneable interface to avoid CloneNotSupportedException. Cloning can be: Shallow Cloning: Copies the object's fields, but not the objects referenced by those fields. Deep Cloning: Copies the object and all objects referenced by it. Example: java class Person implements Cloneable { String name; int age; public Person(String name, int age) { this.name = name; this.age = age; } @Override protected Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException { return super.clone(); } } public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { try { Person original = new Person("John", 25); Person clone = (Person) original.clone(); System.out.println(original.name); // John System.out.println(clone.name); // John System.out.println(original == clone); // false, different objects } catch (CloneNotSupportedException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Runtime polymorphism in Java is the ability of a method to do different things based on the object it is acting upon, determined at runtime. It is achieved through method overriding, where a subclass provides a specific implementation of a method already defined in its superclass. java class Animal { void sound() { System.out.println("Animal sound"); } } class Dog extends Animal { void sound() { System.out.println("Bark"); } } public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { Animal myDog = new Dog(); myDog.sound(); // Outputs "Bark" } }

open_questions.title: The difference between aggregation and composition
open_questions.description: What is the difference between aggregation and composition?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between aggregation and composition?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Aggregation and composition are both types of associations in object-oriented design that describe relationships between objects. Aggregation is a weak association where one object (the whole) contains or uses another object (the part), but the part can exist independently of the whole. For example, a university aggregates departments, but if the university closes, the departments might still exist elsewhere. Composition is a strong association where the part's lifecycle is managed by the whole. The part cannot exist without the whole, and if the whole is destroyed, so is the part. For example, a house composes rooms; if the house is demolished, the rooms cease to exist. Difference: In aggregation, the part can exist independently of the whole, whereas in composition, the part cannot exist independently and is tightly bound to the whole's lifecycle.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: The Java String Pool is a special memory region in the heap where Java stores interned strings. When a new string literal is created, Java checks the pool first: If the string exists, the reference to the existing string is returned. If not, the string is added to the pool. This optimization reduces memory usage and improves performance by reusing common strings. java String s1 = "Hello"; String s2 = "Hello"; System.out.println(s1 == s2); // true, both refer to the same object in the pool String s3 = new String("Hello"); System.out.println(s1 == s3); // false, s3 refers to a different object

open_questions.title: The difference between a shallow copy
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between a shallow copy and a deep copy of an object in Java.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between a shallow copy and a deep copy of an object in Java.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A shallow copy creates a new object but copies the references of the object's fields. Changes to objects within the field will be reflected in both the original and the copy. A deep copy creates a new object and recursively copies all objects referenced by the original object. Changes to objects within the field won't affect the original or other copies. You can create shallow copies using copy constructors or cloning, while deep copies often require custom implementation. java class Item { String name; Item(String name) { this.name = name; } // Deep copy method Item deepCopy() { return new Item(this.name); } } public class CopyExample { public static void main(String[] args) { // Shallow Copy Example ArrayList<Integer> originalList = new ArrayList<>(); originalList.add(1); originalList.add(2); // Shallow copy using clone() ArrayList<Integer> shallowCopy = (ArrayList<Integer>) originalList.clone(); originalList.add(3); System.out.println("Original List: " + originalList); System.out.println("Shallow Copy: " + shallowCopy); // Deep Copy Example Item originalItem = new Item("Java"); // Deep copy using deepCopy() method Item deepCopyItem = originalItem.deepCopy(); originalItem.name = "Python"; System.out.println("Original Item: " + originalItem.name); System.out.println("Deep Copy Item: " + deepCopyItem.name); } } // Output // Original List: [1, 2, 3] // Shallow Copy: [1, 2] // Original Item: Python // Deep Copy Item: Java
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A memory leak and how can
open_questions.description: What is a memory leak and how can it be caused?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a memory leak and how can it be caused?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A memory leak in Java occurs when objects are no longer needed but are still referenced, preventing the garbage collector from reclaiming their memory. Common Causes: Unreleased Resources: Failing to close resources like database connections or streams. Static References: Holding objects in static fields. Long-Lived Objects: Keeping references in collections like ArrayList or HashMap. Inner Classes: Non-static inner classes holding references to outer class instances. Event Listeners: Not removing listeners or callbacks after use. Example: java public class MemoryLeak { private static List<Object> list = new ArrayList<>(); public void addObject() { list.add(new Object()); // Objects added to list are never removed } } In this example, objects added to the static list are never removed, causing a memory leak.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Strings in Java are immutable to enhance security, performance, and thread safety. Immutability means that once a String object is created, its value cannot be changed. Reasons: Security: Prevents modification of sensitive data (e.g., passwords). Performance: Allows string pooling, saving memory. Thread Safety: Immutable objects are inherently thread-safe, avoiding synchronization issues. Example: java String s1 = "Hello"; String s2 = s1; // Both reference the same object s1 = "World"; // s1 now references a new object, s2 still references "Hello"

referenceAnswers.text: An object in Java becomes eligible for garbage collection when it is no longer reachable from any live thread or static references. This typically happens when there are no references pointing to the object, making it inaccessible and unusable by the program.

open_questions.description: Explain dependency injection in Java.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain dependency injection in Java.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Dependency Injection (DI) in Java is a design pattern that allows objects to receive their dependencies from an external source rather than creating them internally. This promotes loose coupling and easier testing. Types of DI: Constructor Injection: Dependencies are provided through the constructor. Setter Injection: Dependencies are provided through setter methods. Field Injection: Dependencies are injected directly into fields. Example: java class Service { // Service class } class Client { private Service service; // Constructor Injection public Client(Service service) { this.service = service; } // Setter Injection public void setService(Service service) { this.service = service; } }

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: In Java, a thread is a lightweight subprocess that enables concurrent execution of code within a program. Threads allow multiple tasks to run simultaneously, improving application performance and responsiveness. Example: java class MyThread extends Thread { public void run() { System.out.println("Thread is running"); } } public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { MyThread t = new MyThread(); t.start(); // Starts the thread } }

open_questions.title: The Java thread lifecycle.
open_questions.description: Describe the Java thread lifecycle.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Describe the Java thread lifecycle.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Java thread lifecycle consists of the following states: New: Thread is created but not yet started. Runnable: Thread is ready to run and waiting for CPU time. Running: Thread is executing. Blocked: Thread is waiting for a monitor lock to enter/re-enter a synchronized block/method. Waiting: Thread is waiting indefinitely for another thread to perform a specific action (e.g., wait()). Timed Waiting: Thread is waiting for another thread to perform an action for a specified waiting time (e.g., sleep(), join(timeout)). Terminated: Thread has finished execution.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Daemon Thread
open_questions.description: What is the Daemon Thread?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the Daemon Thread?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Daemon Thread in Java is a low-priority thread that runs in the background to perform tasks such as garbage collection and handling idle connections. Daemon threads do not prevent the JVM from exiting, even if they are still running, allowing the JVM to terminate when all non-daemon (user) threads finish their execution. This makes them useful for non-critical tasks that should not block the application from quitting. Example: java public class Example { public static void main(String[] args) { Thread daemonThread = new Thread(() -> { while (true) { System.out.println("Daemon thread running"); try { Thread.sleep(500); } catch (InterruptedException e) { Thread.currentThread().interrupt(); } } }); daemonThread.setDaemon(true); // Set the thread as a daemon daemonThread.start(); System.out.println("Main thread running"); try { Thread.sleep(800); // Main thread sleeps for 0.8 seconds } catch (InterruptedException e) { Thread.currentThread().interrupt(); } // Main thread finishes, and JVM will exit, stopping the daemon thread System.out.println("Main thread ends"); } }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Multithreading is a programming technique that allows a single process to execute multiple threads concurrently within the same program. This enables parallel execution of tasks, improving performance and resource utilization by allowing multiple operations to run simultaneously. Example: java public class MultithreadingExample { public static void main(String[] args) { // Creating a new thread using a lambda expression Thread thread = new Thread(() -> { System.out.println("Hello from a separate thread!"); }); // Starting the new thread thread.start(); // Main thread continues executing System.out.println("Hello from the main thread!"); } }

open_questions.description: Define Late Binding.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Define Late Binding.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Late binding in Java, also known as dynamic binding, occurs when the method to be called is determined at runtime rather than compile-time. It allows for polymorphic behavior. Example: java class Animal { void sound() { System.out.println("Animal sound"); } } class Dog extends Animal { void sound() { System.out.println("Bark"); } } public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { Animal myAnimal = new Dog(); myAnimal.sound(); // Outputs "Bark" } } In this example, the sound() method is resolved at runtime based on the actual object type (Dog).
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The different types of Thread Priorities
open_questions.description: What are the different types of Thread Priorities in Java?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the different types of Thread Priorities in Java?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In Java, thread priorities range from 1 to 10, where: MIN_PRIORITY: 1 (lowest priority) NORM_PRIORITY: 5 (default priority) MAX_PRIORITY: 10 (highest priority) Threads with higher priority are more likely to be executed sooner than threads with lower priority, though thread scheduling is ultimately determined by the JVM and the underlying operating system. Example: java class MyThread extends Thread { public void run() { System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " with priority " + Thread.currentThread().getPriority()); } } public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { MyThread t1 = new MyThread(); MyThread t2 = new MyThread(); MyThread t3 = new MyThread(); t1.setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY); // Priority 1 t2.setPriority(Thread.NORM_PRIORITY); // Priority 5 t3.setPriority(Thread.MAX_PRIORITY); // Priority 10 t1.start(); t2.start(); t3.start(); } }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between >> and >>>
open_questions.description: What is the difference between >> and >>> operators in Java?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between >> and >>> operators in Java?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: >> (Signed Right Shift): Shifts bits to the right, preserving the sign (leftmost bit). Fills with the sign bit (0 for positive, 1 for negative). java int x = -8; // Binary: 11111000 int y = x >> 2; // Result: 11111110 (keeps the sign) >>> (Unsigned Right Shift): Shifts bits to the right, ignoring the sign. Fills with zero (always). java int x = -8; // Binary: 11111000 int y = x >>> 2; // Result: 00111110 (fills with zeros)
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Double Brace Initialization in Java is a technique for initializing collections in a concise manner. It combines an instance initializer block with an anonymous inner class, allowing you to add elements to a collection at the time of creation. However, it is less commonly used due to potential memory leaks and readability issues. java List<String> list = new ArrayList<String>() {{ add("Alice"); add("Bob"); add("Charlie"); }};
